articles.headline: China’s Critical Minerals Embargo Is Even Tougher Than Expected
articles.snippet: Beijing ordered companies around the world not to allow critical minerals mined in China to reach the U.S., while deepening its efforts to replace imports with domestic products.
articles.abstract: Beijing ordered companies around the world not to allow critical minerals mined in China to reach the U.S., while deepening its efforts to replace imports with domestic products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarm is rising among multinational companies doing business with China about Beijing’s decision last week to order a trade embargo on the export of four critical minerals to the United States. The central subject of concern is a provision extending the ban to companies in other countries that transfer minerals to American firms after acquiring them from China.

articles.headline: Rupert Murdoch Fails in Bid to Change Family Trust
articles.snippet: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Mr. Murdoch, who was trying to give full control of his empire to his son Lachlan and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant.
articles.abstract: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Mr. Murdoch, who was trying to give full control of his empire to his son Lachlan and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to change his family’s trust to consolidate his eldest son Lachlan’s control of his media empire and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant, according to a sealed court document obtained by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Shock, Glee and Unease as Syrians Celebrate the Unthinkable
articles.snippet: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city.
articles.abstract: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: Syrian security checkpoints sat empty on Monday across Damascus. Abandoned tanks were scattered across the roads, along with stray pieces of military uniforms stripped off by soldiers when opposition forces stormed into the city a day earlier.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: At ‘Tax Prom,’ Washington Prepares for More Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: Republican control of Washington and a tax bill next year have corporate America excited — and on edge.
articles.abstract: Republican control of Washington and a tax bill next year have corporate America excited — and on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life was good for the tuxedoed and gowned tax lobbyists lined up last month along Washington’s waterfront to get into “Tax Prom,” a wonky event even by the standards of a city peopled by policy nerds.

articles.headline: How Crypto Insiders Turned ‘Debanking’ Into a Political Storm
articles.snippet: Concerns that crypto companies are being purposely cut off from the global banking system have become a political cudgel at an opportune moment for the industry.
articles.abstract: Concerns that crypto companies are being purposely cut off from the global banking system have become a political cudgel at an opportune moment for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last year, Ryne Saxe started fielding demands from banks that worked with his San Francisco-based start-up, Eco. They laid out a litany of new compliance and reporting requirements that Eco had to follow.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Israel, Seeing an Opportunity, Demolishes Syria’s Military Assets
articles.snippet: Israel capitalized on the power vacuum in Syria to bomb targets across the country, saying it aims to keep weapons away from extremists.
articles.abstract: Israel capitalized on the power vacuum in Syria to bomb targets across the country, saying it aims to keep weapons away from extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: As soon as it became clear on Sunday that there would be regime change in neighboring Syria, Israel began a sweeping aerial campaign.

articles.headline: Biden Administration Sprints to Tie Up Tech Loose Ends
articles.snippet: Regulators are working around the clock to cement four years of tech policy ahead of the inauguration of President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Regulators are working around the clock to cement four years of tech policy ahead of the inauguration of President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: After last month’s presidential election, Lina Khan, the Democratic chair of the Federal Trade Commission, went into turbo mode.
